unnormalised: It's funny how quickly you can become attached to numbers. Not the abstract kind, but the ones that dictate your daily life. Like the 230 units flashing on my electricity bill every month. Or the 5000 liters of water we apparently guzzle, according to the municipal corporation’s statement. Before moving into our new flat in Bangalore, I barely glanced at these things. Rent, maybe, but utilities? Never really registered.
normalised: It's funny how quickly you can become attached to numbers. Not the abstract kind, but the ones that dictate your daily life. Like the two hundred and thirty units flashing on my electricity bill every month. Or the five thousand liters of water we apparently guzzle, according to the municipal corporation’s statement. Before moving into our new flat in Bangalore, I barely glanced at these things. Rent, maybe, but utilities? Never really registered.

unnormalised: My husband, Rakesh, on the other hand, is a meticulous planner. He tracks everything on spreadsheets. The moment our first electricity bill arrived, displaying a whopping 280 units, he went into "optimize consumption" mode. He started with replacing all the incandescent bulbs with LED ones, costing us around Rs. 1500. A small price to pay, he argued, for long-term savings. I rolled my eyes, picturing him timing my showers next.
normalised: My husband, Rakesh, on the other hand, is a meticulous planner. He tracks everything on spreadsheets. The moment our first electricity bill arrived, displaying a whopping two hundred and eighty units, he went into "optimize consumption" mode. He started with replacing all the incandescent bulbs with L-E-D ones, costing us around rupee one thousand five hundred. A small price to pay, he argued, for long-term savings. I rolled my eyes, picturing him timing my showers next.

unnormalised: The water bill was another beast altogether. 5000 liters! For just the two of us? "Something's leaking," Rakesh declared, launching a full-scale plumbing investigation. He called Mr. Sharma, the building's handyman, who, after a thorough inspection, couldn't find a thing. “Madam, could be your flush,” he suggested helpfully. “Those old models waste 10 liters per flush, easy.” He recommended replacing it with a dual flush system for about Rs. 800.

unnormalised: We also started getting SMS updates from our electricity provider – BESCOM – with our daily consumption. Seeing those numbers tick upwards during peak hours was strangely unsettling. Rakesh even considered installing a smart meter to monitor our usage in real-time. Apparently, those cost around Rs. 2500 installed.

Seeing those numbers tick upwards during peak hours was strangely unsettling. Rakesh even considered installing a smart meter to monitor our usage in real-time. Apparently, those cost around rupee two thousand five hundred installed.

unnormalised: The funny thing is, tracking these numbers made me more aware of our consumption habits. I started switching off lights religiously, taking shorter showers (much to Rakesh’s relief), and only running the washing machine when it was fully loaded. I even started collecting the water from the AC unit to water our small balcony garden.

unnormalised: It wasn't just about saving money, although that was a definite bonus. It became about being more responsible, more conscious of our impact on the planet. Plus, it was kind of a game. Could we beat last month's number? Could we get our water consumption below 4000 liters?
normalised: It wasn't just about saving money, although that was a definite bonus. It became about being more responsible, more conscious of our impact on the planet. Plus, it was kind of a game. Could we beat last month's number? Could we get our water consumption below four thousand liters?

unnormalised: Last month, our electricity bill came down to 210 units. The water bill showed 4800 liters. Rakesh actually fist-pumped when he saw the numbers. Me? I just smiled. We're still attached to those numbers, but now it feels like we're in control, not the other way around. And Mr. Sharma? He got a nice Diwali bonus from Rakesh, well over Rs. 1000, for his helpful plumbing advice, even if it was just the flush!
